talk and Ruby are strongly typed languages, so types DO exist.

 are referring to ManifestTyping
>

Yes, they are strongly typed but also dynamically typed.  When present, =
the
types are enforced, but most of the time, these types are not present..=
.
(and the language won't even let you specify them).

And from your link (=
interesting, thanks), it seems to be synonym to
"manifest typing" indeed.
